content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: find it clear, nice and easy clash
find it perfect :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and easy clash. :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: this would make a great clash

It takes less than 2 minute to solve it in Python so it's nice in "fast mode" challenge.
Explanations are really clear.
I just would have liked a little difficulty cause when you pass the first, you have a great chance to pass all (no trick, no difficulty added)
I think you can add the min and max value of the length of bin in the constraints section
It exists in a similar way, where your can flip one bit and the need to return the longest chain of 1

I've tried it no myself:
1. Why do you give the length of the String as first Parameter? I Think this isn't needed
2. In one Test-Case the Number differs form the Sting Length. Don't remember which one, but the length told was 49, but the String was only 45.
3. I think the "Example"-Section should not be in the Description.
This is good for Reverse-Mode too, I think.
The use of the word "index" in the example is kinda misleading. Guess it could be better to name those as "group 1, index 1", "group 2, index 4" etc.
Not feasible in reverse mode.
I don't see a need for first line in the input. You are not using it in the solution as well.

In the title:
Trail instead of Trailing

In the statement:
• longest chain of "1"s, instead of longest chain of one. (revise the same thing in the Output section)
• multiple longest chain"s" (with "s")
• add "." after "smallest index"
• Index"es" are... (with "es")

In your example, consider just listing all the groups and removing your text explanation ("index = 2 So it refers...refers to")?
bin = 011011100101011010
There are 6 groups in bin as follows:
index 1: 0(11)011100101011010
index 2: 0110(111)00101011010
index 3: 011011100(1)01011010
index 4: 01101110010(1)011010
index 5: 0110111001010(11)010
index 6: 0110111001010110(1)0

Your constraint can be simplified as:
bin is always a non-empty string and always contains at least one "1".
Should I have add more test case or leave it there?

I'd like this problem if we could make the first test case   be:

INPUT
8
10100111

OUTPUT
3
3

Also, I think we should avoid the word "index" here or maybe clarify on what is considered an index

Looks cool. A bit hard to read, though.

Please use a grammar/spelling extension for improved sentences. I've found Gramarly is the best, but I use LanguageTool as well.
I mean, yea, the length is not used in the solution but in some languages like C++, a string could only have so many chracters before it overloads and throw some error
Edit: Has fixed. Fixed in 6:10PM, thank you for help my contribution better. A good day for you!
Yea Ok, I'm gonna fixed it anyways.

Yea, your 2nd advice is true, but the first one is for making string variables in C++ or finite-string languages.

And the 3rd one is unclear, if I remove it then maybe someone will not understand my puzzle at all (Especially at the index part)

So help me to write the stub generator input where it can accepts any input without using any length to limited the string

Like read bin:string[20] (This will only input strings that have maximum 20 characters)

Yes, correct.
Actually is there "length" in the constraints. Replace it with "length of bin", remove the length-Input, and then I didn't see why I can't approve it.
I didn't used the first information about the length of the string

But you could use it to add a trick :
first int : limit of characters to analyse
string : string to analyse
So if the string is longer than the first int, you need to stop your analyse at the int you gave in a first time, if it's higher, you analyse the total string

Oh, I'm sorry, I haven't wrote a Clash myself, so I have no Knowledge about the stub generator.
But it should be possible. Many Clashes have Long Strings as Input...
Maybe you can see a Example in another Contribution?

I just looked myself and found:

read bin:string(964)

Or whatever the longest length of your Input-string is.

I don't use C++, but I think it should be possible to read a variable-length String from StdIn.?!
In worst case, you can read char by char, until you got cr/lf.
A Definition in description, in what Range the Length of the String was, should be added then.

I mean the "*Example"-section in the upper description. i think the Example section at the end (like in other clashes) is enough.
As I have read it, I was confused about the first Section. I thought that I got many lines coming as Input.

Or, if you change to "Reverse-Mode", no Description is needed. ;-)
Edit: The "Example" part has been deleted
